INGREDIENTS:
1 cup quinoa
1 tbsp olive oil
1 garlic clove (minced)
1/2 cup chopped carrots
1/2 cup broccoli florets
1/2 red bell pepper (sliced)
1/4 cup green peas
1/4 tsp turmeric powder
1/4 tsp cumin powder
1 tbsp soy sauce or tamari (low-sodium)
Salt and pepper to taste
Fresh cilantro for garnish
INSTRUCTIONS:
Cook quinoa in 2 cups of water for about 15 minutes or until tender.
In a large pan, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add garlic and sautÃ© for 1 minute.
Add carrots, broccoli, bell pepper, and peas. Stir-fry for 5-7 minutes until vegetables are tender but crisp.
Add turmeric, cumin, soy sauce, salt, and pepper. Stir to coat the vegetables evenly.
Mix in the cooked quinoa and stir for 2-3 minutes until everything is well combined.
Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve.
BENEFITS:
Quinoa: High in protein and fiber, it helps with blood sugar regulation.
Broccoli & Bell Peppers: Packed with antioxidants and vitamins that support hormone health.
Turmeric: Anti-inflammatory properties help reduce symptoms like acne and weight gain.

INGREDIENTS:
3 tbsp chia seeds
1 cup unsweetened almond milk (or any plant-based milk)
1 tsp vanilla extract
1 tbsp maple syrup or honey (optional)
1/2 cup mixed berries (strawberries, blueberries, raspberries)
1 tbsp slivered almonds or walnuts (optional)
INSTRUCTIONS:
In a bowl or jar, mix chia seeds, almond milk, vanilla extract, and maple syrup (if using).
Stir well and let it sit for 5-10 minutes, then stir again to prevent the chia seeds from clumping.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight until it thickens into a pudding-like consistency.
Top with mixed berries and nuts before serving.
BENEFITS:
Chia seeds: Rich in omega-3s, fiber, and protein, which help stabilize blood sugar and improve digestion.
Berries: Low-glycemic fruits loaded with antioxidants, supporting skin health and reducing inflammation.
Almond milk: A low-calorie, dairy-free alternative that helps manage weight and reduce insulin spikes.

INGREDIENTS:
2 cups blanched almond flour
1/4 teaspoon salt
2 tablespoons maple syrup (or sugar-free syrup for keto)
1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
4 large eggs
1/2 cup unsweetened almond milk (or any milk)
Optional: 1 teaspoon baking powder, cinnamon, or chocolate chips
INSTRUCTIONS:
In a bowl, mix almond flour, eggs, almond milk, maple syrup, baking powder, and salt until smooth.
Heat a non-stick skillet over medium heat and lightly grease it.
Pour about 1/4 cup of batter for each pancake onto the skillet.
Cook for about 2-3 minutes until bubbles form, then flip and cook for another minute until golden brown.
Serve warm with your favorite toppings.
BENEFITS:
Gluten-free and low in carbs.
High in protein and healthy fats, which helps keep you full and stabilize blood sugar levels.

INGREDIENTS:

INSTRUCTIONS:
Boil water and add amla juice and tamarind paste.
In a separate pan, heat oil and add mustard seeds until they crackle.
Pour the tempering into the rasam mixture, add salt, and simmer for a few minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves before serving.
BENEFITS: Rich in vitamin C; boosts immunity and aids digestion.

RECIPE NAME: Grilled Chicken Breast with Steamed Broccoli

INGREDIENTS:
2 large eggs
1/2 cup spinach (chopped)
1/4 cup bell peppers (chopped, any color)
1/4 cup mushrooms (sliced)
1/4 cup cherry tomatoes (halved)
1 small onion (finely chopped)
1 tbsp olive oil or coconut oil
Salt and pepper to taste
A pinch of turmeric (optional, for anti-inflammatory benefits)
Fresh parsley or cilantro for garnish (optional)
INSTRUCTIONS:
Heat the olive oil in a large non-stick skillet over medium-high heat.
Add the diced mixed veggies and sautÃ© for about 2-4 minutes until they are softened and lightly browned.
In a bowl, whisk together the eggs, salt, and pepper until combined.
Pour the egg mixture over the sautÃ©ed veggies in the skillet.
Cook while gently folding the eggs back with a spatula, allowing uncooked eggs to flow onto the surface of the skillet. Cook until the eggs are mostly set but still slightly runny (about 1-2 minutes).
If using, sprinkle Parmesan cheese over the top before serving.
BENEFITS:
High in protein, which helps keep you full longer.
Packed with vitamins and minerals from the vegetables.
Low in carbohydrates, making it suitable for managing blood sugar levels.

INGREDIENTS:
20 oz boneless chicken thighs
1 cup cooked quinoa
1/2 cup olive oil
1 tsp salt
1 red onion (minced)
2 tsp garlic (minced)
1 jalapeÃ±o (minced)

INSTRUCTIONS:
Season chicken with salt and cook until done. Allow to cool, then shred.
In a large bowl, combine lettuce and quinoa with half the lime juice and all of the olive oil. Toss to coat.

Serve the chicken mixture over a bed of lettuce and quinoa.
BENEFITS: High in protein and healthy fats; supports satiety and nutrient balance.

RECIPE NAME: Chickpea Pasta with Red Pepper Sauce
INGREDIENTS: Chickpea pasta, roasted red peppers, basil leaves, walnuts, lemon juice.
INSTRUCTIONS:
Cook the Pasta: Boil salted water in a pot. Add chickpea pasta and cook according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
Make the Sauce: In a blender, combine roasted red peppers, olive oil, minced garlic, salt, and pepper. Blend until smooth.
Combine: In a skillet over medium heat, add the sauce and cooked pasta. Toss to combine and heat through for about 2-3 minutes.
Serve: Plate the pasta and garnish with fresh basil or parsley if desired.
BENEFITS:
High in Protein: Chickpea pasta offers a good protein source.
Rich in Fiber: Supports digestion and helps manage blood sugar levels.
Quick and Easy: Perfect for a busy weeknight dinner.

RECIPE NAME: Ragi Dosa with Spinach and Paneer Filling
INGREDIENTS:
For the Dosa Batter:
1 cup ragi (finger millet) flour
1/4 cup rice flour (preferably brown rice)
1/2 cup yogurt (unsweetened)
1 1/2 cups water (adjust for consistency)
Salt to taste
1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds (optional)For the Filling:
1 cup spinach, finely chopped
1/2 cup paneer, crumbled
1 small onion, finely chopped
2 garlic cloves, minced
1 green chili, finely chopped (optional)
1 teaspoon olive oil
Salt and pepper to taste
1/2 teaspoon garam masala
INSTRUCTIONS:
Prepare the Batter:
In a mixing bowl, combine ragi flour, rice flour, yogurt, and water. Whisk until smooth. Add salt and cumin seeds if using.
Let the batter sit for about 10 minutes to allow the flours to absorb the liquid.
Prepare the Filling:
Heat olive oil in a pan over medium heat. Add minced garlic and sautÃ© until fragrant.
Add chopped onions and green chili, cooking until onions are translucent.
Add the chopped spinach and cook until wilted.
Stir in crumbled paneer, garam masala, salt, and pepper. Cook for another 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and set aside.                                                                                                                                                                           Make the Dosas:
Heat a non-stick skillet or dosa tawa over medium heat and lightly grease it with oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the center of the skillet and spread it outwards in a circular motion to form a thin dosa.
Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges and cook until the dosa turns golden brown and crisp.
Assemble:
Place a portion of the spinach and paneer filling on one half of the dosa. Fold the other half over the filling.
Serve hot with coconut chutney or a yogurt-based dip.
BENEFITS:
Benefits:

Ragi (Finger Millet): High in fiber and calcium, helps regulate blood sugar levels and supports bone health.
Spinach: Rich in iron and magnesium, aids in hormone balance and reduces inflammation.
Paneer: Provides high-quality protein, which helps in managing insulin levels and maintaining muscle mass.
Low Glycemic Index: This meal helps in stabilizing blood sugar levels, beneficial for managing PCOS.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup moong dal (yellow split lentils)
2 cups mixed vegetables (pumpkin, beans, carrots, etc.)
1 teaspoon cumin seeds
1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder
1 tablespoon grated coconut
1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds
1 tablespoon coconut oil
Curry leaves
Salt to taste
INSTRUCTIONS:
Cook the moong dal and vegetables together with turmeric powder and salt.
Grind the grated coconut and cumin seeds into a paste.
Add the paste to the cooked dal and vegetables, and simmer for 5 minutes.
In a small pan, heat coconut oil, add mustard seeds and curry leaves, and let them splutter.
Pour the tempering over the kootu and serve with steamed brown rice or millets.
BENEFITS:
Moong dal is high in protein and low on the glycemic index, helping regulate blood sugar.
The variety of vegetables provides essential vitamins, fiber, and antioxidants, supporting overall hormonal balance.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup foxtail millet or little millet
1/4 cup urad dal (split black gram)
1/2 teaspoon fenugreek seeds
Salt to taste
INSTRUCTIONS:
Soak the millet, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 4 hours.
Grind the urad dal and fenugreek seeds into a fluffy batter, then grind the millet.
Mix both batters and allow the mixture to ferment overnight.
Add salt and pour the batter into greased idli molds.
Steam for 10â€“12 minutes until cooked through.
Serve with chutney or sambar.
BENEFITS:
Millets are rich in fiber, iron, and magnesium, helping to control insulin levels.
This is a wholesome, gluten-free breakfast option that supports sustained energy release.

INGREDIENTS:

BENEFITS:
Avial provides a mix of fiber, antioxidants, and probiotics (from yogurt), supporting gut health and hormonal balance.
It is a light, anti-inflammatory dish with healthy fats from coconut.

INGREDIENTS:
1 banana flower (cleaned and chopped finely)
1/2 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas)
1/2 cup chana dal (split chickpeas)
2 dried red chilies
1 teaspoon mustard seeds
Curry leaves
1 tablespoon coconut oil
Salt to taste
INSTRUCTIONS:
Soak the toor dal and chana dal for 2 hours, then grind them with dried red chilies into a coarse paste.
Steam the paste for 10 minutes and crumble it.
In a pan, heat coconut oil, add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Add the crumbled dal paste and sautÃ© for 5 minutes.
Add the finely chopped banana flower and cook until tender.
Serve as a side dish with rice or rotis.
BENEFITS:
Banana flower is rich in fiber, iron, and antioxidants, aiding in digestion and managing PCOS symptoms.
The combination of lentils provides plant-based protein and supports insulin sensitivity.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup boiled chickpeas (or any legume like black-eyed peas, green gram, etc.)
1 teaspoon mustard seeds
1 tablespoon grated coconut
1 dried red chili
1/2 teaspoon urad dal (split black gram)
Curry leaves
1 tablespoon coconut oil
Salt to taste
INSTRUCTIONS:
Boil soaked chickpeas until tender, or rinse and drain canned chickpeas.
Heat coconut or olive oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, asafoetida, dried red chilies, and curry leaves, and sautÃ© for a minute.
Add chopped onions and slit green chili, sautÃ© until onions are translucent.
Add boiled chickpeas, mix well, and cook for 5 minutes to absorb flavors.
Stir in grated coconut and salt, mix well, and cook for 2 minutes.
Remove from heat, add lemon juice, and garnish with coriander leaves.
Serve warm or at room temperature as a healthy snack.
BENEFITS:
Chickpeas: High in protein and fiber, aiding in satiety and blood sugar regulation.
Coconut: Provides healthy fats that support hormone balance and reduce inflammation.
Spices: Mustard and cumin seeds enhance digestion and have anti-inflammatory properties.
Low Glycemic: Suitable for maintaining stable blood sugar levels, beneficial for PCOS management.

INGREDIENTS:
1 tablespoon coconut oil or olive oil
1 teaspoon mustard seeds
1 sprig curry leaves
1 small onion, thinly sliced
2 cloves garlic, minced
1-inch piece ginger, grated
1 green chili, slit (optional)
2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, potatoes, peas), diced
2 cups low-sodium vegetable broth
1/2 cup coconut milk (light)
1 teaspoon turmeric powder
Salt to taste
Fresh coriander leaves, chopped for garnish  '1 teaspoon coconut oil or olive oil
1/2 teaspoon mustard seeds
A pinch of asafoetida (hing)
A few curry leaves
INSTRUCTIONS:
Cook brown rice according to package instructions and set aside.
Heat coconut oil or olive oil in a large pot over medium heat.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add curry leaves and sautÃ© for a minute.
Add sliced onions, minced garlic, grated ginger, and slit green chili; sautÃ© until onions are translucent.
Add diced mixed vegetables and turmeric powder, stirring to coat the vegetables.
Pour in vegetable broth, bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Stir in coconut milk and salt to taste, letting it simmer for another 5 minutes.
In a small pan, heat coconut oil or olive oil, add mustard seeds, and let them splutter.
Add asafoetida and curry leaves, sautÃ©ing for a minute.
Pour the seasoning over the stew and mix gently.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve the vegetable stew hot over brown rice.
BENEFITS:
Provides a good source of fiber and protein from brown rice and vegetables.
Coconut milk adds healthy fats and a creamy texture.
Rich in vitamins and minerals from mixed vegetables.
Helps regulate blood sugar levels, beneficial for PCOS management.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup rolled oats
1 ripe banana
1 cup milk (or plant-based milk)
1 teaspoon baking powder
1 teaspoon cinnamon
1 tablespoon honey or maple syrup (optional)
Coconut oil for cooking
INSTRUCTIONS:
Blend oats, banana, milk, baking powder, and cinnamon until smooth.
Heat a non-stick skillet and lightly grease it with coconut oil.
Pour batter onto the skillet and cook until bubbles form; flip and cook until golden.
Serve warm, topped with fresh fruits or yogurt.
BENEFITS: High in fiber and low in refined sugars, oats help manage weight and control cravings.

INGREDIENTS:
1 head cauliflower, grated into rice-like pieces
2 cups mixed vegetables (peas, carrots, bell peppers)
2 tablespoons soy sauce (low sodium)
1 tablespoon sesame oil
2 cloves garlic, minced
Green onions for garnish
INSTRUCTIONS:
Heat sesame oil in a pan and sautÃ© garlic until fragrant.
Add mixed vegetables and stir-fry for 5-7 minutes.
Stir in cauliflower rice and soy sauce; cook for another 5-7 minutes until tender.
Garnish with chopped green onions and serve hot.
BENEFITS: Cauliflower is low in calories and carbs, making it a great option for weight management.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup spinach or kale
1 banana
1/2 cup Greek yogurt (or plant-based yogurt)
1 cup almond milk (or any plant-based milk)
1 tablespoon nut butter (optional)
INSTRUCTIONS:
In a blender, combine spinach, banana, yogurt, almond milk, and nut butter.
Blend until smooth and creamy.
Pour into a glass and serve immediately.
BENEFITS: A nutrient-packed drink that provides fiber, vitamins, and minerals, helping to manage cravings and energy levels.

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup toor dal (split pigeon peas)
1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, potatoes)
1 onion, chopped
2 tomatoes, chopped
2 tablespoons sambar powder
1 teaspoon mustard seeds
1 teaspoon turmeric powder
Salt to taste
Curry leaves for tempering
Olive oil for sautÃ©ing
INSTRUCTIONS:
Cook toor dal in water until soft. Set aside.
In a pot, heat olive oil, add mustard seeds, and let them splutter.
Add onions, sautÃ© until golden, then add tomatoes, turmeric, and sambar powder; cook for a few minutes.
Add mixed vegetables and enough water; simmer until vegetables are tender.
Stir in cooked dal and salt, simmer for 5 minutes. Serve hot with rice or idli.
BENEFITS: Packed with lentils and vegetables, sambar is high in protein, fiber, and vitamins, making it great for overall health.
